vectorData.altText: 7. Capillaries of the choroid plexus are of the ______________ type.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
That’s right! Capillaries of the choroid plexus are fenestrated to allow production of CSF.

Most cerebral BVs in the parenchyma of the brain are of the continuous type, and form the blood-ISF barrier. Recall that the anatomical basis of the blood-ISF barrier is the presence of TJs between adjacent endothelial cells of brain capillaries and selective molecular transporters within their cell membranes.
In contrast, BVs of the choroid plexus are fenestrated. The extravasation of plasma components across their walls, into the sub-adjacent CT, is unimpeded by tight junctions between endothelial cells. This provides the raw material for CSF production. 
Choroid ependymal cells stand between this CT fluid and the ventricular space. Unlike the ependymal cells lining the walls of ventricles, choroid ependymal cells are joined by TJs. Therefore, CSF is produced by the active secretion of molecules into the ventricles by choroid ependymal cells.
Normal CSF is clear, colourless, and low in protein, cells and IgG.
